column9: NO. The German translation is more polite and lacks the intensity and frustration of the original English phrase. A better translation would be: "Willst du mich verarschen?!"
column10: NO. The German translation "Machst du Witze?!" is more like "Are you joking?". A better translation that captures the tone and intent of the original English phrase would be "Willst du mich verarschen?!" or "Machst du Witze mit mir?!"

column9: NO. The German translation "Ich sage es nur!" is more literally "I'm just saying it!" A better translation would be "Ich sage ja nur!" which captures the tone and intent of the English phrase "I'm just saying!"

column9: The texts do not have the exact same meaning. While both convey interest, "intriguing" suggests something is interesting because it is unusual or mysterious, whereas "faszinierend" is more general and can simply mean very interesting. A better translation would be: "Das ist faszinierend."
column10: The texts do not have the exact same meaning. While both convey interest, "intriguing" suggests something is interesting because it is unusual or mysterious, whereas "faszinierend" is more general and can simply mean very interesting. A better translation would be: "Das ist faszinierend."
